title: Brian Hibbard
text:
Brian Hibbard (26 November 1946 – 17 June 2012) was a Welsh <a href="actor">actor</a> and <a href="singing">singer</a> from <a href="Ebbw%20Vale">Ebbw Vale</a>, <a href="Wales">Wales</a>, best remembered as the lead vocalist in the original <a href="The%20Flying%20Pickets">The Flying Pickets</a>.
Early life and career.
Hibbard was born into a <a href="working%20class">working class</a> family in <a href="Ebbw%20Vale">Ebbw Vale</a>, <a href="Monmouthshire%20%28historic%29">Monmouthshire</a>, and had a <a href="History%20of%20the%20socialist%20movement%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">socialist</a> upbringing. He was educated at Ebbw Vale Grammar School. After various jobs including teacher, steel worker, barman and <a href="chimney%20sweep">chimney sweep</a>, he formed The Flying Pickets with a group of other actors who had practised <a href="a%20cappella">a cappella</a> singing while travelling by coach to their appearances.
Following the group's success in the early 1980s, Hibbard went on to pursue a career as a <a href="television">television</a> actor, appearing in "<a href="Coronation%20Street">Coronation Street</a>" as garage mechanic Doug Murray, in "<a href="Emmerdale">Emmerdale</a>" as <a href="Bobby-John%20Downes">Bobby-John Downes</a>, and as Johnny Mac in the <a href="Welsh%20language">Welsh language</a> <a href="soap%20opera">soap</a> "<a href="Pobol%20y%20Cwm">Pobol y Cwm</a>" as well as the youth drama "Pam Fi, Duw?". In 1995 he played Jason in an episode of the fifth series of Heartbeat He was in the 1997 film "<a href="Twin%20Town">Twin Town</a>" as the self-styled "Karaoke King" Dai Rees. He has also appeared in the drama serial "<a href="Making%20Out%20%28TV%20series%29">Making Out</a>"; in the "<a href="Doctor%20Who">Doctor Who</a>" story "<a href="Delta%20and%20the%20Bannermen">Delta and the Bannermen</a>"; in comedy in "<a href="The%20Armando%20Ianucci%20Shows">The Armando Ianucci Shows</a>"; in Series 9 Ep 3 of "<a href="Minder%20%28TV%20series%29">Minder</a>", and "<a href="Satellite%20City">Satellite City</a>"; and in the film "<a href="Rancid%20Aluminium">Rancid Aluminium</a>". Hibbard appeared in "<a href="EastEnders">EastEnders</a>" from 4 to 8 July 2011 playing <a href="Henry%20Mason%20%28EastEnders%29">Henry Mason</a>, a man who ran a children's home where <a href="Billy%20Mitchell%20%28EastEnders%29">Billy Mitchell</a> and <a href="Julie%20Perkins">Julie Perkins</a> were in care.
Death.
In 2000, Hibbard was diagnosed with <a href="prostate%20cancer">prostate cancer</a>; he died of the disease on 17 June 2012 at the age of 65. He is survived by his wife Caroline and their three children.
